Award.AwardTitle: FESD Type-1: Electrical Connections and Consequences Within the Earth System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Millions of lightning flashes occur per day over the Earth, transferring tremendous power from electrical clouds to Earth's surface in the form of electric current. Lightning discharges also occur between the clouds and the edge of space, producing luminous displays called sprites and elves. These events can occur because cosmic rays from other galaxies and x-rays from the Sun make the edge of space electrically-conducting. It is not well understood how lightning might modify ionospheric conditions that affect communications and navigation (e.g., GPS) systems, or how changes in the space environment might affect electrical processes in polar-region clouds relevant to weather and climate, or how society would be impacted in other ways through electrical connections within the Earth-atmosphere-geospace system. This Broad topic is the subject of the project "Electrical Connections and Consequences Within the Earth System".

It is the purpose of this 5-year multi-institutional basic research investigation to better understand the electrical processes that link together the atmosphere, solid earth and geospace components of the Earth system. The approach is to develop improved understanding of processes controlling the charge and discharge of electrified clouds, the electrical coupling between the atmosphere and ionosphere, and the flow of current throughout the system. The project will culminate in creation of a global model that is capable of replicating much of the experimental data accumulated to date, and that Interfaces with the rest of the atmosphere-ionosphere system within the Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM) at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR). Other key goals of this project are to educate the public about this field of study, and to motivate and educate a cadre of next-generation scientists on this global view of the Earth-atmosphere-geospace system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are all aware of lightning flashes, and the tremendous power that they can transfer from electrical clouds to Earth's surface in the form of electric current. But did you know that millions of lightning flashes occur per day over the Earth?  That lightning discharges also occur between the clouds and the edge of space, producing luminous displays called sprites and elves?  That cosmic rays from other galaxies and x-rays from the Sun make the edge of space electrically-conducting so that these events can occur?  That currents in the ionosphere can induce dangerous current surges in our power grid system? That lightning emits powerful electromagnetic radiation? Or that the signatures of interactions between charged particles from the Sun and Earth's outer magnetic field can be measured at the ground in the polar regions?  One begins to wonder how lightning might modify ionospheric conditions that affect communications and navigation (e.g., GPS) systems, or how changes in the space environment might affect electrical processes in polar-region clouds relevant to weather and climate, or how society would be impacted in other ways through electrical connections within the Earth-atmosphere-geospace system.  This broad topic was the subject of the project “Electrical Connections and Consequences Within the Earth System (ECCWES)”, led by investigators at the University of Colorado, the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR), and Penn State University. 

Global weather and climate models currently incorporate physical, dynamical, and chemical processes, but do not consider the electrical processes within the atmosphere. The focus of ECCWES was to better understand the electrical processes that link together the atmosphere, solid earth and geospace components of the Earth system.  In ECCWES this was done through development of improved understanding of processes controlling the charge and discharge of electrified clouds, the electrical coupling between the atmosphere and ionosphere, and the flow of current throughout the system.  The project culminated, in part, in creation of a global model that calculates global conductivities, fair?weather electric fields and currents self consistently within the model atmosphere, and replicates the measured mean global diurnal behavior of electric potential and electric field.

One key element of the global modeling included specification of source currents. This was done by using thunderstorm overflight measurements from NASA’s ER2 aircraft to parameterize relationships between thunderstorm cloud and electrified non-lightning cloud properties and source currents. Using global specifications of cloud properties from Tropical Rainfall Measuring Mission (TRMM) and Global Precipitation Mission (GPM) satellite observations, these parameterizations then enabled specification of the global distribution of electrical source currents.

Another issue central to the project was how individual lightning discharges, spatial-temporal variability of electrified clouds, and related conductivity perturbations translate to global electric circuit (GEC) characteristics.   Advances in this area were achieved by means of numerical simulation using a fully time-dependent model that included Earth as a conductor with finite conductivity in addition to fully resolved dynamics of charges and currents in the Earth’s lower atmosphere and ionosphere. Specific scientific contributions made under this part of ECCWES included understanding (1) the contributions of different types of lightning discharges to the GEC; (2) how clouds modify electrical conductivity; (3) how large-scale conductivity variations in the Earth’s atmosphere (due to gamma ray bursts, topography and thunderstorm activity) modify the GEC;  and (4) how current sources inside the conducting Earth can lead to the electrical gas discharges sometimes observed near Earth’s surface during strong earthquakes.  

At higher levels, in the ionosphere (ca. > 100 km), electric fields and currents react to atmospheric winds pushing plasma through Earth’s magnetic field, to gravity and plasma pressure gradient forces, to magnetospheric currents, and to fair weather and thunderstorm currents from the lower atmosphere.  A new three-dimensional electro-dynamo and ionospheric current model was developed with the goal of evaluating the importance of these different forces and sources for the atmosphere-ionosphere electric field. It was determined that the impact of lower atmosphere fair weather and thunderstorm currents on the ionospheric electrodynamics are relatively small.  However, a major demonstration of the model was that 3-dimensional current flow, and gravity and pressure gradient currents, were all important factors in determining magnetic perturbations in the ionosphere. This finding will lead to an improvement in the interpretation of magnetic measurements from orbiting satellites. Another potential impact is that more realistic modeling of ionospheric currents will lead to improved Earth conductivity modeling.

An important element of ECCWES was educating the general public and K-12 students about Earth’s electrical system. A 26-page Teacher’s Guide on the GEC, A Guide to Engaging Hands-on Activities for Students in Atmospheric Static Electricity, and a YouTube video were produced (all available at https://scied.ucar.edu/atmospheric-electricity). In addition, the project engaged 5 undergraduate students including 4 from UCAR’s SOARS (Significant Opportunities in Atmospheric Research and Science) Program, 7 graduate students and 6 post-docs.
